column4: hi, i'm interested in creating an ubuntu installer USB stick without deleting what's on my USB stick or using fancy GNOME software
i just want to put vmlinuz and initrd and an iso image on the stick, as i do with debian
is this possible?
Yes.
will unetbootin delete my exitsing files a3ther_?
No.
could you elaborate please?
i set iso to load the initrd and kernel i copied from the install cd, but it complains that it "can't find medium with live filesystem"
i set isolinux*

The easiest way to do it is to use unetbootin or Ubuntu's "Startup Disk Creator", neither of which will delete existing files. If for some reason that's not acceptable (why?) then you can copy the iso to the flash drive, create a grub.cfg as explained here: http://www.supergrubdisk.org/wiki/Loopback.cfg#How_do_you_use_a_loopback.cfg_to_boot_an_iso.3F then install grub2 to the drive with grub-install.
nice, thank you Jordan_U
You're welcome.
I pressed the wrong button in unetbootin and it wrote to my system's boot drive.  that's why i don't like fancy GNOME utilities
Do you need help fixing it?
well, i removed the files it wrote there, and re-installed my system grub to that device
i hope it works
so nobody here can just tell me what unetbootin is going to do to my stick, so i can do it myself?
if it's supposedly safe
also the unetbootin packaged in debian doesn't have 10.10
If you're doing it manually the grub2 route is easier.

If your flash drive were "/dev/sdb" then it would basically be: sudo mount /dev/sdb1 /mnt; sudo cp /path/to/ubuntu_10.10.iso /mnt/; sudo grub-install --root-directory=/mnt /dev/sdb; sudo vi /mnt/boot/grub/grub.cfg" where the grub.cfg would follow the template here: http://www.supergrubdisk.org/wiki/Loopback.cfg#How_do_you_use_a_loopback.cfg_to_boot_an_iso.3F
